title: Domino's Pizza retreats from overseas markets as sales fail to satisfy
text:
Domino's Pizza is set to pull the plug on it sizeable international operations as sales in these markets remain lacklustre.

Outgoing chief executive David Wild said today that, following a review of the division - which spans Iceland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland - the firm is better off selling out and focusing on its core UK market, where it has more than 1,100 shops.

'We have concluded that, whilst they represent attractive markets, we are not the best owners of these businesses. The board has therefore decided to exit the markets in an orderly manner,' he said.

Domino's Pizza is set to pull the plug on it sizeable international operations, it said today

Overseas sales slumped 2.7 per cent to £25million in the past three months as it started to sell off stores. The international division was expected to break even this year, but losses have spiralled in several markets.

Wayne Brown, an analyst at Liberum, said the retreat was 'likely to be complex', but will give the firm space to refocus on its UK and Ireland operation, which also faces challenges as a dispute with some of its franchisees rolls on and puts the breaks on new store openings.

In May, Domino's said talks were ongoing after franchisees protested against receiving a smaller cut of the profits.

Wild, who has held the top job at the pizza chain since 2014 and is set to step down, said: 'Normal working practices continue to be impacted by our franchisee dispute.

'As we said at our interim results, this situation is complex and we expect a resolution to take time, certainly into 2020. We remain committed to working with our franchisees to agree sustainable win-win solutions.'

The firm said the search for Wild's successor, as well as a new chair, is ongoing.

Russ Mould from AJ Bell said that Domino's may have had 'eyes bigger than their stomachs'

In the past three months, the company's UK and Ireland sales gained pace, growing 3.9 per cent to £288million.

Domino's has recently felt the heat from fresh competition in the industry, such as Deliveroo and Uber Eats, which continue to eat into the takeaway market.

Russ Mould, investment director at AJ Bell, said that Domino's may have had 'eyes bigger than their stomachs' when it came to expanding into overseas territories 'which have unfortunately resulted in indigestion'.

He added, however, that pulling out is 'the sensible thing to do'.

'Management should be applauded for making the decision to pull out rather than digging themselves a bigger hole,' he said.

'There is now a real opportunity to fix Domino's which has lost its way in recent years thanks to over-expansion, deteriorating relationships with franchisees, international woes and heightened competition.'

Shares advanced by more than 3 per cent in early trading to £2.80.
